repnme.cdata!:
Islamic Republic of Iran - Bam Earthquake
            Emergency Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Bam Earthquake Emergency
            Reconstruction Project for Islamic Republic of Iran were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            it is important that the Bank understands and serves the
            client's needs when there has been little previous
            interaction by preparing upfront capacity building on
            Bank's processes and procedures. In the context of
            interrupted engagement, projects should be designed to be
            modular and requiring less interdependence between
            components, with a simple design and deliberate and
            thoughtful preparation. There should be a shortened project
            horizon rather than components/projects which require a
            long, steady relationship. When a project is to move quickly
            because of an emergency situation, arrangements must be made
            to ensure that project design is kept simple. Future project
            design should avoid considering a broad range of sectors
            under the umbrella of a single emergency project. It is more
            effective to focus projects on specific sectors and
            activities that are directly related to the immediate
            reconstruction efforts. Presence of a local office in the
            country invariably helps resolve issues in a timely manner.
            The revised guidelines for emergency projects provide
            flexibility to project teams not to require counterpart funds.

repnme.cdata!:
Iran - Bam Earthquake Emergency
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bam Earthquake Emergency
            Reconstruction Project (BEERP) for Iran aims to (a) restore
            the living conditions of the communities affected by the
            earthquake, (b) improve emergency preparedness in the
            Province of Kerman and the city of Bam, and (c) strengthen
            the planning and management capacity under the
            reconstruction program. Considering the complexity of the
            reconstruction efforts and taking into account the
            Bank's country and international experience in
            earthquake projects, the project will be implemented over a
            four-year period. The funding of the reconstruction program
            relies primarily on Government financing as well as support
            from the World Bank, the Japan Bank for International
            Cooperation, the Islamic Development Bank and countries from
            the Persian Gulf and Europe. There are five project
            components (some with multiple subcomponents): 1) provision
            of construction material and equipment for housing and
            commercial buildings; 2) repair of the transport
            infrastructure; 3) repair of the telecommunications
            infrastructure; 4) improved emergency preparedness in the
            province of Kerman and the district of Bam; and 5) project
            management and technical assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Iran - Bam Earthquake Emergency
            Reconstruction Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This Social and Environmental Screening
            and Assessment Framework (SESAF) has been developed
            specifically for the proposed sub-projects under the Bam
            Earthquake Emergency reconstruction Project in Iran, to
            ensure due diligence, to avoid causing harm or exacerbating
            social tensions, and to ensure consistent treatment of
            social and environmental issues by project authorities, and
            those involved with the project. The framework shall assist
            in the selection of sub-projects, to avoid or minimize as
            possible, any likely social and/or environmental impact,
            identify mitigation, and enforce compliance. In most cases,
            mitigation will be inherent in standard engineering design
            and construction practices. Investments considered to impose
            unacceptable negative environmental impacts will not be
            approved for financing. Checklists have been prepared to be
            submitted with each subproject prior to approval. Any
            subproject causing potential damage to cultural heritage
            sites, will not be financed, as neither will any subproject
            concerning construction of new primary roads or highways.
            Subprojects eligible for project financing include (subject
            to environmental screening approval): provision of equipment
            and construction material for housing and commercial
            buildings; repair of transport infrastructure (airport
            facilities, highway repairs, and village streets);
            telecommunication networks; retrofitting works of the key
            strategic buildings in the Province of Kerman. As part of
            the social framework, the report also addresses
            resettlement, and indigenous population issues.
